en: Interview with Mike Werner, 2020-02-20

Interview with Mike Werner, Mayor of Gatlinburg. Werner discusses the day of the fire and the heavy smoke in the air and the surprising speed at which the fire reached the city. He also recounts balancing his professional respsonsibilities to Gatlinburg while also managing the loss of his own home in the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Our downtown was saved. If we would've lost our downtown, it wouldn't have been a few years to recover, it would've been decades."

Interview with Mike Werner, Mayor of Gatlinburg. Werner discusses the day of the fire and the heavy smoke in the air and the surprising speed at which the fire reached the city. He also recounts balancing his professional respsonsibilities to Gatlinburg while also managing the loss of his own home in the disaster. This is a representative quote from the interview: "Our downtown was saved. If we would've lost our downtown, it wouldn't have been a few years to recover, it would've been decades."

Interview with Mike Werner, 2020-02-20 -- Gatlinburg
Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Mike Werner, 2020-02-20
Interview Questions
Would you state your name and tell us about your history with Gatlinburg?
What brought you to Gatlinburg? Can you tell us some of your personal history?
What did you first notice in the week precedig the fire?
Were you still living in Walden's Creek when the smoke was so thick in Gatlinburg?
Which morning was it that you couldn't see Gatlinburg due to the smoke?
Who was with you that went to Knoxville?
What time did you leave Gatlinburg?
Were you just leaving to go to dinner and then come back?
Did your sone stay at your home the entire time that evening?
What are the people telling you when the call?
Are these friends that are calling you? How much did they know?
How did you respond after all the calls?
So people were calling you about the damage?
Can you describe being on the Spur as you approach the fire?
Did you come in on 441?
Who was at the briefing?
Did you use the phrase "Mountain Tough?" Did it originate with you?
Once you've come into Gatlinburg, do you know anything about your home or business?
What were you anticipating as you were going to your home?
What was your emotional reaction to seeing the destruction?
How much of your personal possessions did you lose?
When did you get a chance to see your home for yourself? What was your reaction?
What do yo believe happened to your home?
What do yo believe happened to your home?
Had you gone back to work at any point when you were moving around?
Can you describe how the fire impacted you emotionally?
How did the loss of your personal belonging impact you?
How did this even impact you financially?
How did you stay in touch with the Gatlinburg community and media after the fire?
How did the residents of Gatlinburg assess the recovery effort?
As a Midwesterner, did the outpouring surprise you?
Do you think people are upset about your actions personally, or the negativity is a response to something larger?
From your perspective, how did the fire shape community relations?
What did the City of Gatlinburg do to bring tourism back?
Do you have any idea why there was so much disinformation?
Did you meet any of the families of those that lost their lives?
What was it like meeting these families?
Is there anything else that you would like to add?
Where do you go from here?
